awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Tracing Diversification of Ceremonial Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
The contemporary social landscape of East Africa is closely linked to pastoral immigration and the reshaping of identities over the last several millennia. Doctoral dissertation researcher Lorraine Hu will study early processes of social differentiation among herding groups by examining localized variability in burial customs. Previous scholarship on the spread of nomadic societies to this region has emphasized economy and subsistence, focusing on the aspects of daily life that make pastoralism distinct from sedentary or hunter-gatherer lifeways. Other cultural practices, though more difficult to trace in deep time, are equally important to understanding how groups create and negotiate fluid social landscapes. Archaeology is well-equipped to provide insight into questions of social variability by tracing changes in local customs over the long term. Understanding how communities choose to define their own identities through maintaining or changing traditions has relevance for many herding groups today, where processes of globalization complicate boundaries of both identity and subsistence. The project will build partnerships through providing training opportunities for Kenyan students and promote cultural heritage education in East Africa and the USA.

Dr. Fiona Marshall and Lorraine Hu of Washington University in St. Louis will examine the development of funerary practices of early pastoralist groups in East Africa. The research will be conducted in southern Kenya where a tradition of cremation, unique to the area, developed between 3000-1000 years ago when herders first migrated into the highlands. These early pastoralists are known to have developed distinct lithic and ceramic traditions, but social variability across communities is yet unknown. Research on funerary customs aims to elucidate localized differences. By combining excavation, sedimentological sampling and study of skeletal material from previously excavated cremation sites, the researchers will reconstruct cremation burial practices from different sites. Integrated sediment and skeletal analyses allow detailed study of pyrotechnic processes, and in conjunction provide a new approach to mortuary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The population interactions and movements that occurred throughout Africa during the development of various forms of food production are an important factor underlying the diversity of the modern cultural landscape. In eastern Africa, a twice-yearly rainfall regime and rangeland environments have attracted pastoralists and contributed to their long-term success in the region for thousands of years. These ecological factors feature prominently in the influences that shape pastoralist lifeways, but a rich anthropological and historical record also illustrates how relationships and social institutions play a significant role in the longevity and resilience of herding societies in the modern day. Herders in the present day have developed diverse social practices, institutions, and networks of relationships that connect individuals across wide areas. These ties contribute significantly to the long-term resilience of pastoralism, as they act as social safety nets in times of resource scarcity brought on by factors such as drought or disease.

Though these social aspects of herding lifeways are highly important in recent times, little is known about the community-making practices of the earliest pastoralists in the region, especially as they would have been advantageous when navigating novel physical and social landscapes. Research on the Pastoral Neolithic (PN) period, c. 3300-1200 BP in southern Kenya and northern Tanzania, has revealed much about the chronology, subsistence, and material expressions of early pastoralists, but understandings of fundamental social aspects of early herding groups, such as their burial practices, are not well understood. This project focused on the reconstruction of cremation and burial practices in southern Kenya including Noomparrua Nkosesia, Njoro River Cave, and Keringet Cave. These communal burial sites, unmarked by gravestones or other funerary architecture, are all situated in secluded or otherwise physically restricted environments of caves and underground cavities, and present a unique environment to study the maintenance of ritual practice through time. Skeletal, sedimentological, and infrared spectroscopy analyses were used to examine different stages and aspects of the overall funerary process to determine whether sites exhibited similarities in cremation and burial practices.

Skeletal analyses of cremated remains took place in the National Museum of Kenya in the fall of 2019 and spring of 2020. Sedimentological and infrared spectroscopy analyses were conducted at Washington University in St. Louis in 2021. Differences among the three sites are most apparent in the presence of subadults at Njoro River Cave and Keringet Cave, body condition (i.e., fleshy bodies versus dry bones), and funeral pyre intensity. Notably, cut marks and the proportion of peripheral body elements from Keringet Cave demonstrate possible postmortem manipulation, and skeletal remains from Noomparrua Nkosesia may have been cremated as dry bones. Several common factors among sites in addition to the cremation itself, including the rocky environment of the burials, lower-intensity cremation of lower body elements, and deposition of ochre in association with the upper body, demonstrate the preservation of fundamental practices for up to two millennia. These results support the notion that cremation rites emphasized collective, integrating actions through site reuse and co-presence of multiple burials. The materialization of funerary processes in covert spaces, unmarked by lasting commemorative structures or any other permanent anthropogenic indicator, suggest that the production and acquisition of knowledge of cremation was maintained through collective participation and memory that drew together and reinforced ties between groups of herders throughout the PN period.

This project also included comparative morphological and material analyses of small ground stone vessels found at the cremation sites. These analyses took place at the National Museum of Kenya in spring of 2020. Using a previously established comparative metric of height-to-diameter ratio of ground stone bowls, we demonstrated that the vessel assemblage from Noomparrua Nkosesia is more morphologically diverse than that of Njoro River Cave, the only other stone bowl assemblage comparable in magnitude. However, the bowls at Noomparrua Nkosesia were deposited alongside few burials (MNI 5) compared to Njoro River Cave (MNI 84). With this comparison in mind, we hypothesize that a wide range of individuals may have been involved in crafting vessels that were eventually included in the funerary deposits at Noomparrua Nkosesia, once again emphasizing the collective actions necessary to materialize these funerary environments.

Together, these results and discussions add a unique perspective to the theorization of early pastoralism in eastern Africa as well as pastoralist mortuary archaeology more broadly, as global considerations of pastoralist burial traditions largely focus on monuments and other stone constructions. Cremation sites of the PN were hidden, covert spaces, but even in the absence of anthropogenic markers they still acted as socially significant places of revisitation and convergence over extended periods of time.
